instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Green Light, but won't turn on.
Liquid Damage near by <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> and the board was properly cleaned.
I Trigged <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and nothing happen.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.56V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 3.2V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>/S4 = 0 NO PULSING

Any hint, helps!
Thank you

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0V"
A good reason for PCH to stay "calm".

Check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> level.
If good, reball SMC.

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
QuickQuestion:
What makes you think the problem is on the SMC?

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> --> SMC --> <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> --> PCH, as per schematic note (page 59).
Check also <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5192</RESISTOR>).

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: SMC Reballed and looks the same.

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: SMC Replaced and i got all those missing rails back, however the <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is missing.

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Check first diode mode to ground at L7630.
Inspect <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area for corrosion.

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
L7630 = 0.117 and going UP
<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> No corrosion

threads.title: 820-000165 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
Check traces, solders and resistors; especially <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR>/12 and R/<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>.
If all good, change the chip...
